newsitem.title: CANADA: Weston sees higher 1997 operating net.
newsitem.headline: Weston sees higher 1997 operating net.

text.p: Bakery and foodstuffs firm George Weston Ltd will post higher operating earnings this year than in 1996, President Richard Currie told reporters on Wednesday after the annual meeting.
Last year, Weston earned C$5.02 a share or C$239 million, including a C$1.16 a share or C$87 million gain from the C$225 million sale of the Neilson confectionary businesss.
"We'll make the same without the capital gain as we made with it," Currie said. "That's a material increase in earnings."

Currie said Weston would see a double-digit sales increase at wholly owned food retailer, which had 1996 sales of C$2.4 billion. He added that Loblaw's 1997 earnings per share would be in line with analysts' forecasts of C$0.83 to C$0.89.
Loblaw accounts for 77 percent of Weston's sales.

Currie said subsidiary Weston Foods would turn a profit, but added that paper and forest products unit E.B. Eddy "will be hard pressed to make a gain, but they'll have a reasonable year, certainly a lot better than most people are having in the pulp and paper industry right now."
Forestry firms have been hurt by dropping paper prices.

Currie did not rule out selling non-core assets such as Eddy. "I don't know the answer to that until we get all these businesses operating the way we want them to operate," Currie said. On the other hand, "we could make it bigger," he said.
Only Loblaw was considered a core business, Currie said.
Asked at the meeting about a stock split, Currie said: "At $100 we'll talk about it."
Weston shares rose 0.25 to 79 on the Toronto Stock Exchange today in light trading.
